Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Optical Frequency, Quantum Magnetic Resonances for Photonic Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this research is to develop a new class of optical frequency metamaterials that leverage magnetic dipole transitions in Lanthanide ions for photonic device applications.

Intellectual Merit: Recent metamaterials research has expanded the range of materials and phenomena available for photonic devices. Whereas most metamaterials exploit artificial magnetic resonances in lossy metallic structures, this program explores the natural magnetic dipole transitions in Lanthanide ions. Enhancing these quantum magnetic resonances promises to enable the development of continuous, low-loss, isotropic metamaterials. Such metamaterials would have direct application in the areas of nanoscale lithography and imaging. Moreover, metamaterials incorporating Lanthanide ions offer the intrinsic gain necessary to realize amplification in newly proposed designs for nanoscale optical circuits and lasers.

Broader impacts: Lanthanide ions are light emitters in a board range of technologies from fluorescent lighting and color displays to lasers and fiber-optic amplifiers. This program leverages the societal and technological relevance of Lanthanide materials to: (i) advance cutting-edge research in the applied areas of optical devices and solid-state lighting, and (ii) improve the education of students from a diverse range of ages, backgrounds and disciplines. Specific plans include: (1) development of new interdisciplinary course on the "Art & Science of Light"; (2) continuation of summer workshop series to promote hands-on laboratory training; (3) expansion of SearchLight Project to raise awareness for energy and environmental implications of lighting; (4) development of new educational modules in collaboration with NSF-supported GK-12 "Physical Processes in the Environment" program for the Providence Public School system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although light is an electromagnetic wave, it is often assumed that all light-matter interactions at optical frequencies are mediated by electric fields through electric dipole (ED) transitions. Nevertheless, there are light emitters that exhibit strong magnetic dipole (MD) transitions. In fact, we see MD emission every day from the many lanthanide ions (such as erbium, europium, and terbium) that help to illuminate everything from fluorescent lighting to telecom fiber amplifiers. Despite their importance to many photonic device technologies, the MD contributions to many important emitters had not been fully characterized when we began this research program. Thus, the goal of this CAREER proposal was to study these optical-frequency, quantum magnetic resonances for new and improved photonic devices.

Intellectual Merit: This CAREER award supported an exploratory program to investigate the natural magnetic dipole (MD) transitions in lanthanide ions. The specific goals of the program were to: (1) develop new optical tools to characterize MD emission, (2) design optical structures to enhance and control MD transitions, and (3) demonstrate new degrees of freedom for device design by exploiting MD transitions. We are proud to have achieved all of these goals. In particular, we: (1) developed energy-momentum spectroscopy as a robust technique to directly quantify MD transitions; (2) designed simple and practical multilayer systems to enhance and control MD transitions, and in so doing, helped developed for the nano-optics community a detailed understanding of the distinct electric, magnetic, and electromagnetic LDOS; and (3) showed how competing ED and MD transitions can be used to mechanically and optically modulate light-emission faster than the excited state lifetime. 

Broader Impact: This CAREER award also supported significant education and outreach activities, including: the doctoral research of two graduate students, research experience for seven undergraduate students, significant curricular development including a new interdisciplinary course on the Art and Science of Light (ENGN1930W) with Prof. Paul Myoda, the world-renowned sculptor and co-creator of the “Tribute in Light” memorial at the World Trade Center; founding the Brown Nanoscale Fabrication & Characterization Workshops to support the hands-on training of scientists and engineers throughout Rhode Island; championing the SearchLight Project and related activities to engage students and the local community in reimagining efficient lighting technology such as the large-scale lantern exhibit at the Granoff Center for the Creative Arts; participating in the Spira summer camp for local female high school students at Brown and at science conferences at local elementary schools organized by NSF K-12 Fellows; and mentoring a local high school teacher through the MRSEC RET program.  

Publications and Research Products: In addition to the major accomplishments listed above, this CAREER award has resulted in at least 12 publications in the leading journals of our multidisciplinary field. These include publications in the journals of the American Physical Society (Physical Review B and Physical Review Letters), the American Chemical Society (ACS Nano and Nano Letters), the American Institute of Physics (Applied Physics Letters), the Optical Society of America (Optical Materials Express, Optics Express and Optics Letters), and the Nature Publishing Group (Nature Communications and Nature Nanotechnology).
